greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = number of distinct prime factors of n that are < the square of smallest prime factor of n, a(1) = 0.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10001
formula: a(n) = Sum_{p|n, p prime and < spf(n)^2} sign(p), where spf(n) (A020639) gives the smallest prime factor of n, and sign(p) = A057427(p) = 1 for all p.
example: For n = 4 = 2*2, the prime factor 2 is less than 2^2, and it is counted only once, thus a(4) = 1.
For n = 45 = 3*3*5, both prime factors 3 and 5 are less than 3^2, thus a(45) = 2.
mathematica: Table[If[n == 1, 0, Count[#, d_ /; d < First[#]^2] &@ FactorInteger[n][[All, 1]]], {n, 120}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Mar 24 2017 *)
program: (PARI) A(n) = if(n<2, return(1), my(f=factor(n)[, 1]); for(i=2, #f, if(f[i]>f[1]^2, return(f[i]))); return(1));
for(n=1, 150, print1(omega(n/a(n)),", ")) \\ _Indranil Ghosh_, after _David A. Corneth_, Mar 24 2017
def a(n): return 1 if A(n)==1 else A(n)*a(n//A(n))
print([omega(n//a(n)) for n in range(1, 151)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Mar 24 2017
xref: Cf. A284262 (where obtains first time value n, also positions of records).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Mar 24 2017
